markdown: Executive Vice President's Message <::A black and white portrait of a man wearing glasses, a suit jacket, and a patterned tie. He is looking directly forward with a neutral expression.: figure::> In 1975, the American Heart Association moved from New York to a newly- constructed National Center in Dallas. Volunteer leaders of the Association determined that a geographically central location and modern facilities would bring about operating efficiency and economies. This new building is the nerve center of our voluntary mission to reduce premature death and disability from cardiovascular diseases. It becomes the focal point of an organization comprising 40,000 of America's foremost scientists and physicians, 65,000 other key members and more than 2,000,000 citizen volunteers. As a meeting place and resource center for the dedicated workers of the American Heart Association, our new National Center now enables closer relationships and communications with 55 Affiliates and 1,196 Chapters and Units. It is also national headquarters of the Association. Planned and executed with long-term savings in mind, this relocation is but a part of the Association's strategy to refine management practices and to implement economies and confront the challenge of fiscal restraint. In this regard, I am pleased to report that combined expenditures by the national office and all affiliates for fund raising and other overhead costs have been reduced dramatically from a high point of 30 percent in the 1968 fiscal year to a low of 23 percent in the fiscal year ending last June 30. To have curbed overhead while increasing and expanding our program is a remarkable achievement, not only from a management standpoint, but also for what it contributed toward our public accountability. By practicing economies and instituting other solid management devices, the Heart Association has been able to channel almost 80 cents of every dollar spent into positive programs for the public's benefit. By improving the processes of our planning and management systems, we are further developing orderly mechanisms for doing an even better job and determining future priorities, objectives, and costs. Thus, we will be increasingly able to approach the public with targeted needs, rather than simply our overall program of research, education, and community services. In this manner, I am confident Americans will respond even more positively. William W. Moore Executive Vice President OFFICERS Richard D. Dotts Chairman of the Board John T. Shepherd, M.D., D. Sc. President Harriet P. Dustan, M.D. President-Elect Elliot Rapaport, M.D. Immediate Past President Ross Reid Immediate Past Chairman of the Board VICE PRESIDENTS Philip P. Ardery Owen Beard, M.D. John J. DeFeo, Ph.D. Mrs. Frank A. Dresslar, Jr. Ham Jackson, M.D. Kenneth W. Kihle, M.D. Ira L. Lavin John G. Martin Edward Meilman, M.D. Nanette K. Wenger, M.D. Stanford Wessler, M.D. James G. White, M.D. John S. Andrews Treasurer Mrs. M. Jeanne Pontious, R.N. Secretary BOARD OF DIRECTORS Walter H. Abelmann, M.D. Boston, Mass. William H. Ames, M.D. St. Joseph, Mo. John S. Andrews Youngstown, Ohio Philip P. Ardery Louisville, Ky. Adm. Philip F. Ashler Tallahassee, Fla. W. Gerald Austen, M.D. Boston, Mass. Owen Beard, M.D. Little Rock, Ark. Rene Bine, Jr., M.D. San Francisco, Calif. Miss Virginia Black, R.N. Cheyenne, Wyo. Reagan H. Bradford, Ph.D. Oklahoma City, Okla. Guy E. Bramon, Jr. Bloomfield, Conn. Miss Grace Brown, R.N. Riverdale, N.Y. Jay D. Coffman, M.D. Boston, Mass. William E. Conner, M.D. Portland, Ore. B. Trent Cooper, M.D. Roanoke, Ind. Robert J. Cruikshank Houston, Tx. Gordon Curren Sisseton, S. Dak. Vincent DeCristofaro Providence, R.I. John J. DeFeo, Ph.D. Kingston, R.I. Richard D. Dotts Newport Beach, Calif. Mrs. Frank A. Dresslar, Jr. Fresno, Calif. Harriet P. Dustan, M.D. Cleveland, Ohio Robert R. Eddy Concord, N.H. William H. Eells Columbus, Ohio Blair D. Erb, M.D. Knoxville, Tenn. Allan L. Friedlich, M.D. Boston, Mass. Emilio R. Giuliani, M.D. Rochester, Minn. Samuel Goldfein, M.D. Tucson, Ariz. Judith Graham, M.D. Great Falls, Mont. Jared Grantham, M.D. Kansas City, Ks. 15 Source: https://www.industrydocuments.ucsf.edu/docs/tlnf0227 14

In 1975, the American Heart Association moved from New York to a newly- constructed National Center in Dallas. Volunteer leaders of the Association determined that a geographically central location and modern facilities would bring about operating efficiency and economies. This new building is the nerve center of our voluntary mission to reduce premature death and disability from cardiovascular diseases. It becomes the focal point of an organization comprising 40,000 of America's foremost scientists and physicians, 65,000 other key members and more than 2,000,000 citizen volunteers.

As a meeting place and resource center for the dedicated workers of the American Heart Association, our new National Center now enables closer relationships and communications with 55 Affiliates and 1,196 Chapters and Units. It is also national headquarters of the Association. Planned and executed with long-term savings in mind, this relocation is but a part of the Association's strategy to refine management practices and to implement economies and confront the challenge of fiscal restraint.

In this regard, I am pleased to report that combined expenditures by the national office and all affiliates for fund raising and other overhead costs have been reduced dramatically from a high point of 30 percent in the 1968 fiscal year to a low of 23 percent in the fiscal year ending last June 30. To have curbed overhead while increasing and expanding our program is a remarkable achievement, not only from a management standpoint, but also for what it contributed toward our public accountability. By practicing economies and instituting other solid management devices, the Heart Association has been able to channel almost 80 cents of every dollar spent into positive programs for the public's benefit.

By improving the processes of our planning and management systems, we are further developing orderly mechanisms for doing an even better job and determining future priorities, objectives, and costs. Thus, we will be increasingly able to approach the public with targeted needs, rather than simply our overall program of research, education, and community services. In this manner, I am confident Americans will respond even more positively.
William W. Moore Executive Vice President
